sections.title: Building a Stock Portfolio
sections.subtitle: Create a diversified portfolio that matches your goals

sections.title: Portfolio Construction Basics
sections.content:
A portfolio is simply a collection of investments. Building a good portfolio isn't about picking the hottest stocks - it's about creating a mix of investments that work together to achieve your goals while managing risk.

The key principle is diversification: don't put all your eggs in one basket. By spreading investments across different stocks, sectors, and asset classes, you reduce the impact of any single investment going wrong. A well-diversified portfolio can weather market storms better than a concentrated one.

points.title: Asset Allocation
points.description: The split between stocks, bonds, and other assets. This is the biggest driver of returns and risk. A common rule: subtract your age from 110 to get your stock percentage. A 30-year-old might have 80% stocks, 20% bonds.

points.title: Diversification
points.description: Spread investments across sectors (tech, healthcare, finance), company sizes (large, mid, small cap), and geographies (US, international, emerging markets). Aim for 20-30 individual stocks minimum, or use index funds for instant diversification.

points.title: Risk Tolerance
points.description: How much volatility can you stomach? If a 30% drop would make you panic sell, you need a more conservative allocation. Be honest with yourself - your risk tolerance during a bull market is different than during a crash.

points.title: Time Horizon
points.description: Money needed in 1-3 years shouldn't be in stocks. For 5+ year goals, stocks historically outperform. The longer your horizon, the more risk you can take because you have time to recover from downturns.

points.title: Rebalancing
points.description: Over time, winners grow and losers shrink, throwing off your target allocation. Rebalance annually by selling some winners and buying more of underperformers to maintain your target mix.

sections.title: Portfolio Strategies
sections.content:
Core-Satellite Approach: Put 70-80% in broad index funds (the 'core') for diversification and low costs. Use 20-30% for individual stocks or sector bets (the 'satellites') where you have conviction.

Dividend Growth Strategy: Focus on companies with long histories of increasing dividends. These tend to be stable, profitable businesses. Reinvest dividends to compound returns.

Value Investing: Buy stocks trading below intrinsic value. Requires patience - value stocks can stay cheap for years before the market recognizes their worth.

Growth Investing: Focus on companies with high revenue and earnings growth. Accept higher valuations for faster growth. More volatile but potentially higher returns.

Index Investing: Simply buy the whole market through index funds. No stock picking required. Historically beats most active managers over long periods.

sections.title: The Power of Index Funds
sections.content: Over 15-year periods, about 90% of actively managed funds underperform their benchmark index. For most investors, a simple portfolio of 2-3 index funds (US stocks, international stocks, bonds) will outperform complex strategies. Keep it simple.

sections.title: Building Your First Portfolio
steps: Define your goals and time horizon - retirement in 30 years? House down payment in 5 years?
Assess your risk tolerance honestly - how would you react to a 40% drop?
Choose your asset allocation based on goals, timeline, and risk tolerance
Decide between index funds, individual stocks, or a combination
If picking stocks, diversify across at least 5-7 sectors
Start with your largest positions in your highest-conviction ideas
Set up automatic investments to build positions over time (dollar-cost averaging)
Review and rebalance quarterly or annually
Keep some cash (5-10%) for opportunities during market dips

sections.title: Sample Portfolio Allocations
sections.content:
Aggressive (Young investor, 30+ year horizon):
- 60% US Stock Index Fund
- 25% International Stock Index Fund
- 10% Small Cap/Growth Stocks
- 5% Bonds

Moderate (Mid-career, 15-20 year horizon):
- 45% US Stock Index Fund
- 20% International Stock Index Fund
- 10% Individual Stocks
- 20% Bond Index Fund
- 5% REITs

Conservative (Near retirement, 5-10 year horizon):
- 30% US Stock Index Fund
- 10% International Stock Index Fund
- 10% Dividend Stocks
- 40% Bond Index Fund
- 10% Cash/Money Market

These are starting points - adjust based on your specific situation.

sections.title: Common Portfolio Mistakes
sections.content:
Over-concentration: Putting too much in one stock, even if you love the company. No single position should exceed 5-10% of your portfolio.

Home country bias: US investors often put 100% in US stocks. International diversification reduces risk and captures growth elsewhere.

Chasing performance: Buying last year's winners often means buying high. Past performance doesn't predict future results.

Over-trading: Frequent buying and selling racks up costs and taxes. Most investors do better with a buy-and-hold approach.

Ignoring costs: High expense ratios and trading fees compound against you. Choose low-cost index funds when possible.

Emotional decisions: Panic selling during crashes and euphoric buying during bubbles destroys returns. Stick to your plan.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: The best portfolio is one you can stick with through good times and bad. It doesn't need to be perfect or complex. A simple, diversified portfolio that you maintain consistently will outperform a 'perfect' portfolio you abandon during the first downturn.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: You now have the foundation to start building your stock portfolio. Open a brokerage account if you haven't already, decide on your allocation, and start investing. Remember: time in the market beats timing the market. The best time to start was yesterday; the second best time is today.
